CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--"Mr. Goldman, are you a Communist? The rumor is that you are. Several of my classmates assume that if an American criticizes his economy, he must be a Communist." That was one of the many surprising reactions I encountered last fall at Moscow State University in my course on the United States economy, the first ever taught there by a nonMarxist economist.

MALIBU, Calif., Jan. 24 (UPI)--A gust of wind today knocked down a frame house being built for the actress Lee Grant in the Point Dume area, causing damage estimated at $70,000, sheriff's deputies reported. They said that two workmen had heard the frame structure creaking in the wind, then ran to safety just before it collapsed.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--Governor Carey sought today to break up a name-calling dispute between his Corrections Commissioner and his chief state prison watchdog by ordering them to meet and agree to "exchange information" before criticizing each other in public.

BUFFALO, Jan. 24--Rick Martin and Gil Perreault, the Buffalo Sabres' entrants in the National Hockey League's annual All-Star Game, gave their home crowd a thrill tonight by scoring the tying and winning goals in the Prince of Wales Conference's 3-2 overtime victory over the Campbell Conference.

The New York Mets yesterday hired a physical fitness expert, Paul Mastropasqua, to work with the team in spring training as well as during the regular season. The 39-year-old Mastropasqua, a native of Hoboken, N.J., has been working with athletes for 20 years and has been associated with a New York City health club, the New York Jets and a summer football camp.

ONE OF THE questions that seems to loom large in the home cooks's mind is whether or not foods can be cooked with equal success under a broiler or on top of the stove, using a skillet. It is an understandable dilemma, for foods cooked under the broiler generate a good deal of smoke and odors in small facilities without proper ventilation.

American Airlines, in an unaudited report, announced yesterday that its earnings in 1977 rose to a record of $81.9 million, up from $56.3 million, or $1.97 a share, in 1976. Revenues increased to $2.28 billion from $2.01 billion.

TRENTON, Jan. 24--New Jersey is losing farm's to developers at the rate of one every three days and as a result farmland preservation has become "the No. 1 priority" in the State Department of Agriculture, the department's secretary, Phillip Alampi, said today.

The New York City Fire Department Pension Fund is running out of money and, for the first time, its expenses will exceed its income this year. Unless an agreement is reached soon on additional contributions by the city, the firefighters' union, or both, the fund will have to start selling its stocks, bonds and other assets to pay pensions.

The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday increased its dividend for the last quarter of 1977 by 10 percent to 55 cents a share, despite a 9.3 percent slide in net income for the last quarter of 1977, to $59.6 million, or 78 cents a share, from $65.7 million, or 89 cents a share, in the comparable period in 1976.

LOWRY, Minn.--Scores of farmers and their wives gather nearly every weekday morning these days in the old, two-story fire hall in this snowswept western Minnesota village to vent their anger over the high-voltage power lines for which surveyors are preparing the way across their county.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--Jack Pardee, who coached the Chicago Bears into the National Football League play offs last season, was signed today to coach the Washington Redskins, the Redskins' owner, Edward Bennett Williams, announced. Pardee was signed to a multiyear contract, but the terms were not disclosed.

THE last we heard from Bobby Seale, former chairman of the Black Panther Party was in 1973, when he drew a surprising 43,719 votes, compared with 77,476 cast for the winner, in a runoff campaign for the mayoralty of Oakland, Calif.

ROME, Jan. 24--Prime Minister-designate Giulio Andreotti was ostensibly consulting with smaller parties today to explore ways of solving the government crisis, but the significant contacts were understood to be taking place with the Communist Party in secrecy.

CHARLIE MORROW called his solo performance at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Monday evening "a night of vision chanting," but it was more than that.

MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP)--Eastern Airlines, which hasn't paid a cash dividend to common shareholders in more than eight years, proposed today to issue scrip that would enable shareholders to fly for as little as half-fare.

The Xerox Corporation, the world's leading manufacturer of copying duplicator equipment and supplies, reported yesterday profit increases of 18 percent for the final quarter and 12 percent for all of 1977.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (AP)--Topseeded Jimmy Connors defeated Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 7-6, 6-0, tonight to reach the second round of the $225,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis tournament.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--Expressing alarm that nearly 10 percent of the nation's auto thefts occur in the New York City area, the state's Insurance Superintendent said today that he was considering a legislative drive to crack down on the auto-theft industry and on the insurance frauds that flourish with it.

A 15-story midtown apartment house that was cleared of its tenants a few years ago in anticipation of office development on the site has come full circle. It is to be rehabilitated as an elegant apartment house, in which twobedroom apartments will rent at about $1,200 a month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Dr. Karl Z. Morgan, an expert on the health hazards of radiation, testified today that the Federal Government should reduce the amount of radiation that nuclear workers and the public are exposed to.

The credit markets, nervous about the dollar and concerned about whether G. William Miller will be confirmed as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, resumed their downward course yesterday as they headed toward the Treasury's $5 billion refinancing announcement scheduled today.

MOSCOW, Jan 24 (AP)--A United States national wrestling team dropped the first match of its Soviet tour today, 9-1, to the Soviet national team in Yerevan, Armenia, according to Tass, the Soviet news agency. NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP)--The New Orleans Fair Grounds canceled all nine races scheduled for today because of weather conditions. It rained the last three days.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 1 (AP)--A Mahwah man has been ruled not guilty by reason of insanity in the Election Day stabbing death of his crippled father.
